title-group.article-title: IgG4-Related Plasmacytic Enteropathy Mimicking Ulcerative Colitis

article-meta.aff: 1Dokkyo Medical University School of Medicine, Shimotsuga, Japan

author-notes.corresp: Johji Imura, Dokkyo Medical University School of Medicine, Kitakobayashi 880, Mibu, Shimotsuga 321-0293, Japan Email: imura@dokkyomed.ac.jp

body.p: A 58-year-old man presented with continuous diarrhea and mucinous stool. He had a history of primary sclerotic cholangitis previously diagnosed by cholangiography and bile duct mucosal biopsy. Serum levels of IgG4 were slightly increased to 117 mg/dL. Total colonoscopy revealed scattered erosion, edema, and petechiae in the mucosa, which was consistent with ulcerative colitis (Figure 1). Randomly biopsied specimens from lesions showed moderate inflammatory changes in the mucosa. Although the infiltrating cells were mainly composed of lymphoplasmatic cells (Figure 2, hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification 20×), plasmacytes producing IgG4 predominated (Figure 3, immunohistochemistry for IgG4, original magnification 20×). These findings support a diagnosis of IgG4-related plasmacytic enteropathy.

caption.p: Colonoscopic findings. Multiple erosions and petechia scattering in the colonic mucosa
Colonic biopsy specimen showing diffuse lymphoplasmacytic infiltration into the lamina propria
Immunohistochemical finding. The IgG4 positive plasmacytes occupying the predominance of the infiltration cells
